conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions,

I’m Student_E. Thank you for continuing to consider my messages throughout the process.

Since School_C is still unmatched at this stage, could you please clarify what would need to happen for the remaining seat to be offered? Specifically:
1) Are you still actively expecting any higher-priority students to apply/accept School_C, or are they already matched elsewhere?
2) If those students do not apply, is there a point (or round) when you would release the seat to the next available candidate?
3) Is there any way for me to be placed as a confirmed next-in-line/waitlist candidate so you can fill the seat immediately if it becomes available?

School_C remains my first choice, and if an offer becomes possible, I am ready to commit immediately.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. This maximizes my chance of timing an eventual acceptance if the higher-priority students are already matched elsewhere.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your thoughtful questions and for your continued interest in School_C.

1) We are still keeping our single seat available in case a higher-priority applicant (relative to our admissions order) applies to School_C. While we do not have perfect visibility into other schools’ ongoing conversations in real time, we must assume that at least some higher-priority candidates could still reach School_C depending on how their top choices play out.

2) Because we have only one seat, we cannot commit it early without risking losing the ability to admit a higher-priority applicant who may apply later. That said, as the process gets closer to the end, the likelihood of new higher-priority applications decreases. If we reach a late stage and no higher-priority applicants have applied to us, we will reassess and may begin filling the seat.

3) The current protocol doesn’t provide a binding “waitlist/next-in-line” mechanism. However, you are welcome to continue checking in. If you choose to submit an [APPLY] again at a later round, we will evaluate immediately based on whether any higher-priority applicants are actively in consideration at that time.

If it helps, you can message us again around the later rounds (e.g., after a few more rounds have passed) to see whether our position has changed.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[TALK]

Since your last message indicated the seat was being held as a precaution (rather than for an applicant currently in active consideration), may I ask whether any higher-priority students have contacted or applied to School_C since then? If not, I would be very grateful if you could now fill the seat so that School_C does not risk ending the process unmatched.

Thank you again for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. Prior attempts were rejected due to a precautionary hold for higher-priority students, but School_C has also stated no higher-priority applicants were actively in consideration recently. In Round 12, it is optimal to apply again while directly asking whether any higher-priority student has actually contacted/applied since our last exchange, and to emphasize immediate commitment to help them avoid ending unmatched.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for applying again in Round 12 and for your continued commitment to School_C.

To answer your question: since our last message, we have not received any new contact or application from a higher-priority student this round. Given the stage of the process and the ongoing risk of remaining unmatched, we are now prepared to fill our seat.

We are pleased to offer you admission to School_C. If you still wish to commit, we will finalize the match upon your acceptance.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority order is B > A > D > E > C, and I have quota 1. Student_E is acceptable but not top-tier for me. However, by Round 12, only Student_E is repeatedly applying; no higher-priority students have contacted School_C at all. Looking at student preferences: Student_B ranks School_C 2nd (after School_E), Student_C ranks School_C 2nd (after School_D), Student_A ranks School_C last, Student_D ranks School_C last. The only plausible higher-priority candidate who might still come is Student_B if rejected by School_E, but School_E prioritizes Student_E first and Student_B second; Student_B may already be matched or likely to match elsewhere. Continuing to hold risks ending unmatched, which is strictly worse than matching with Student_E (who is on my list). Given late round and repeated commitment, it is now optimal to accept Student_E to secure a filled seat rather than gamble on a late arrival from B/A/D.
